title: GoodHang CS Assessment
completionMessage: Assessment complete. Your results are being analyzed.
scoringPhilosophy: Hard grading: 50 = average. Most candidates score 40-60. Elite performers (top 10%) score 85+.

sections.title: Who You Are
sections.description: Quick personality and work style questions
sections.transitionMessage: Great start. Now let's dig into your CS expertise.

questions.text: Hey! Tell us a bit about yourself - who you are, what you're working on, and anything else you'd like us to know.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: authenticity, warmth, communication style, what they choose to highlight. No wrong answers - this is about getting to know them as a person.

questions.text: When you're under significant stress at work, what does your behavior look like? Be honest - we all have patterns.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: genuine self-awareness, specific behavioral patterns, evidence of growth. Red flag: 'I thrive under pressure' without nuance. Maps to Enneagram stress patterns.

questions.text: What kind of humor do you enjoy most? Describe how you like to spend time with friends - what makes for a great hangout?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: specificity, authenticity, social preferences, warmth. Red flag: 'I don't have time for fun' or overly performative answers.

questions.text: What's a belief you held strongly 5 years ago that you've since changed your mind about? What changed it?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: intellectual humility, specific example, clear reasoning about what changed. Red flag: can't think of anything or picks something trivial.

sections.title: Strategic Account Management
sections.description: How you manage complex enterprise relationships
sections.transitionMessage: Now let's get into the hard CS scenarios.

questions.text: Your executive sponsor just resigned with no notice. Walk me through exactly what you do in the first 72 hours.
questions.scoring_guidance: Elite answers include: immediate outreach to other contacts, research on successor, internal escalation, risk assessment, documentation of relationship history. Look for multi-threading awareness and urgency without panic.

questions.text: You have 50 accounts. You can only give white-glove attention to 10. What's your framework for deciding which 10?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: multi-factor framework (ARR, expansion potential, risk, strategic value, logo value). Red flag: only mentions revenue or only mentions risk. Elite answers acknowledge tradeoffs.

questions.text: Your customer's IT team wants one thing, their business team wants another, and they're both your stakeholders. The requests are mutually exclusive. How do you navigate this?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: stakeholder mapping, understanding underlying needs vs stated wants, facilitation skills, escalation path awareness. Elite answers bring parties together rather than picking sides.

questions.text: Describe a QBR you ran that actually changed the trajectory of an account. What made it different from a checkbox QBR?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: specific outcomes, executive engagement, data-driven insights, strategic recommendations. Red flag: describes a standard update meeting. Elite answers show QBR as strategic inflection point.

sections.title: Churn & Retention
sections.description: How you fight for customers and learn from losses
sections.transitionMessage: Let's talk about the hard conversations.

questions.text: Tell me about a customer you lost that you initially classified as 'unavoidable churn' - acquisition, went out of business, etc. Looking back now, what would you do differently?
questions.scoring_guidance: Key insight: 'unavoidable churn' mindset is toxic. Elite CSMs find leverage even in hard situations. Look for: root cause analysis, earlier intervention opportunities, systemic learnings. Red flag: still blames external factors.

questions.text: You need to communicate a 15% price increase to a strategic account that's already frustrated with your product. Walk me through your approach.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: direct language (not 'adjustment'), value-first framing, acknowledgment of their frustration, creative options (multi-year lock, value trades like case studies). Red flag: avoids the conversation or leads with apology.

questions.text: A customer is churning and there's genuinely nothing you can do to save them - the decision is made. How do you handle the offboarding? What do you try to accomplish?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: graceful exit, learning extraction, door-left-open mentality, reference/referral ask, internal feedback loop. Elite answers see offboarding as relationship continuation, not ending.

sections.title: Expansion & Growth
sections.description: How you identify and execute growth opportunities
sections.transitionMessage: Now let's talk about growing accounts.

questions.text: Describe 3 implicit signals that a customer is ready for expansion - signals they wouldn't directly tell you.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: usage patterns, org changes (hiring, new initiatives), questions about features outside current scope, champion promotion, increased executive engagement. Red flag: only mentions explicit asks.

questions.text: What's the difference between a CSM who 'supports' expansion and one who 'drives' it? Which are you, and why?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: understanding of the spectrum, honest self-assessment, specific examples. Elite answers show nuance - knowing when to drive vs support based on context.

questions.text: You've identified a significant expansion opportunity but your sales counterpart isn't prioritizing it. How do you handle this?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: collaboration skills, data-driven persuasion, escalation judgment, understanding of sales priorities. Red flag: goes around sales or gives up. Elite answers build cross-functional trust.

sections.title: Onboarding & Time-to-Value
sections.description: How you get customers to success quickly
sections.transitionMessage: Let's talk about getting customers started right.

questions.text: You're designing onboarding for a new enterprise customer segment you've never served before. How do you identify their 'aha moment' and what's your approach to setting a time-to-value target?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: customer research methodology, segment-specific thinking, measurable TTV targets, understanding that 'aha moment' varies by persona. Red flag: one-size-fits-all answer.

questions.text: An enterprise customer's onboarding is stalling because their internal champion doesn't have bandwidth to drive adoption. What do you do?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: finding alternative champions, escalation to exec sponsor, reducing champion burden, creative engagement tactics. Elite answers address root cause (champion capacity) not symptom (slow adoption).

sections.title: Internal Influence & Product
sections.description: How you advocate internally for customers
sections.transitionMessage: Now let's talk about working with your own company.

questions.text: Give me an example where you successfully got a product feature prioritized. What data did you bring? What approaches didn't work before that?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: data-driven approach, understanding of product priorities, persistence with iteration, cross-functional relationship building. Red flag: just escalated or complained.

questions.text: A customer escalates an issue that's actually caused by a limitation in your product that won't be fixed soon. How do you handle both the customer and internal stakeholders?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: transparent communication with customer, workaround creativity, internal escalation without blame, setting realistic expectations. Elite answers are 'product shields' while maintaining customer trust.

sections.title: AI & Systems Thinking
sections.description: How you leverage AI and think about complex systems
sections.transitionMessage: Let's see how you work with AI tools.

questions.text: How does the Internet work?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: clarity of explanation, appropriate depth, ability to simplify complex concepts. Elite answers show layered understanding (physical, protocol, application layers) without being pedantic.

questions.text: How are you currently using AI tools in your CS work? Give me 2-3 specific examples with the actual prompts or workflows you use.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: specific, practical applications; prompt sophistication; workflow integration. Red flag: vague 'I use ChatGPT for emails' without specifics. Elite answers show systematic AI integration.

questions.text:
**Scenario:** You need to analyze 50 customer support tickets to identify common themes and prioritize which issues to address first.

**Your Task:** Write the EXACT prompt you would give to an AI tool to help you analyze these tickets.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: clear instructions, structured output request, categorization framework, priority criteria. Elite prompts show understanding of prompt engineering - context, constraints, format.

questions.text:
**Scenario:** You're designing a customer health scoring algorithm. You have: product usage (logins/week), support tickets, NPS score, contract value, days since last engagement, and executive sponsor engagement.

**Your Task:** Write the EXACT prompt you would give to an AI to help you design this scoring system.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: understanding of weighted factors, awareness of edge cases, request for reasoning, practical implementation focus. Elite answers translate business intuition into AI-executable tasks.

questions.text: When should you NOT use AI? Give me 3 specific CS scenarios where AI would be the wrong choice.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: emotional conversations, legal/compliance sensitivity, creative strategy, relationship moments. Red flag: can't think of limitations. Elite answers show AI judgment, not just AI enthusiasm.

sections.title: Self-Awareness & Growth
sections.description: Final questions about who you are

questions.text: What's the biggest gap in your CS skillset right now? What are you doing about it?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: genuine self-awareness, specific gap identification, concrete improvement plan. Red flag: 'I work too hard' or false humility. Elite answers show growth mindset with action.

questions.text: Describe a time you received feedback that was hard to hear. How did you respond in the moment vs. after you had time to process?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: honest initial reaction, processing journey, behavioral change. Maps to Enneagram integration/disintegration patterns. Elite answers show emotional maturity arc.

questions.text: What energizes you at work? What drains you? Be specific.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: specific examples, self-knowledge, honesty about limitations. Helps identify role fit and potential burnout risks. Elite answers show pattern recognition in their own motivation.
